translation2: Since its introduction in 2001, the Valvetronix series from VOX has continuously evolved, leading to the combination of advanced modeling technology with the "Valve Reactor" circuit, which perfectly imitates the behavior of a tube amplifier. With the VT20X/VT40X/VT100X amplifiers, we are presenting a brand new modeling engine that is absolutely state-of-the-art in terms of sound. Thanks to the VET (Virtual Element Technology) technology, which is based on the analysis of components and amplifier circuits, the VTX amplifiers wait with an authenticity that is absolutely impressive. Of course, these amps also include the multi-stage Valvetronix tube preamplifier, which partly relies on genuine analog circuits because these better capture the variations and nuances of a tube amplifier than any simulation. In addition to this sophisticated circuitry, the VTX amplifiers offer a closed housing and a bass reflex system, from which the natural resonances just flow. With the "Tone Room" software from VOX, you can even correct and bend historical facts on the virtual level until the amp and effects sound exactly as you have always imagined them. The perfect combination of tube sound with modeling technology is primarily due to the 2001 introduced VOX Valve Reactor technology. Of course, it has been refined several times since then to meet new sound requirements, which led to a performance boost of the VOX Valvetronix series in 2010 - with more dynamics as well as numerous and significantly improved amplifier models. From the compact VT20+ to the VT120+ with two speakers, the new VT+ Valvetronix series has been designed in such a way that all guitarists searching for maximum sound diversity will find what they are looking for. All guitarists dream of the compression and dynamics of a tube amplifier: they expect a fat sound, a nuanced reproduction of playing dynamics and string attack, as well as a prompt response. During an in-depth analysis, the VOX engineers discovered that the output stage determines the tube character of an amplifier and developed the VOX Valve Reactor technology based on this finding. The Valve Reactor circuit of each VT+ amplifier, equipped with a 12AX7 tube, perfectly reproduces the behavior, subtle nuances, and sound character of a tube amplifier.

translation2: Basketball Bundesliga: Disastrous Derby Defeat for MHP Riesen Ludwigsburg against Merlins Crailsheim  At least one youngster, Johannes Patrick, was left out. Again, nothing: For the second time in less than three months, the Riesen lost in Crailsheim - and how! Before the game, Ludwigsburg's coach John Patrick had looked back on the cup defeat in October at the Hakro Merlins Crailsheim and said: "We still have some anger in our stomachs." However, this anger did not subside after the game, but rather intensified due to the 61:72 (28:38) defeat in the Basketball Bundesliga. Whereas the result alone was disappointing, it was the way the team performed that was even more disappointing. For example, a statistic that expresses the entire dilemma: The three-point percentage was only 13 percent, with four shots (all by young Johannes Patrick) out of 31 attempts - more questions? John Patrick's answer: "We were not concentrated enough after our victory in Tenerife and did not implement what we had trained." In other words, moving the ball. His opponent, Sebastian Gleim, reacted quite differently: "It was an amazing game to win for the second time against Ludwigsburg," said the happy coach. "It felt like in front of 10,000 people." Meanwhile, only 750 spectators were allowed in the Hohenlohe Arena on Saturday, but they made up for it. Not least because of BBL top scorer T.J. Shorts, who scored 22 points and led his team to victory. "The best playmaker I have ever trained," praised Gleim. Meanwhile, in Patrick's team, the key performers such as Jordan Hulls (0 points) and Jonah Radebaugh (7) failed across the board. Only in the last quarter (22:15) did the Riesen prevent a total disaster and came within eight points of a comeback, after they had already trailed 39:59. In addition to Johannes Patrick, Justin Simon also scored 12 points. Luckily, there is not much time left for brooding. Already on Wednesday (7:00 p.m.), the Riesen will receive the Skyliners Frankfurt, before they also play in Ludwigsburg in front of a maximum of 750 spectators.

translation2: In the name of the people: Laypeople hand down judgments. In the courtroom, they sit in everyday clothes on the judge's bench. But much depends on their judgment, even if they don't wear a robe: Jurors decide with professional judges how long someone will be behind bars. Two of them, Sascha Wickert from Boos and Ruth Ertz from Bad Kreuznach, report in an interview with the "Public" about their time at the Bad Kreuznacher Landgericht: They are two of a total of 125 lay judges at the Landgericht an der John-F.-Kennedy-Straße.

translation2: I am bored with Sky Sport F1 Hello dear F1 fans, throughout the season, the quality on the German Sky has gradually decreased, so I want to vent a bit in this post. First of all, the transmission was interrupted during the F2 race to start the F1 coverage on time. Although the delayed start and the start accident put the schedule far behind schedule, the last (planned) ten minutes as well as the championship decision (!) could still have been shown. However, it seems that for legal reasons, F1 has priority and everything else has to be restricted, so Sky DE here probably had no choice. Nevertheless, it is still stupid, especially since Sky UK broadcast the race to the end. Nevertheless, a small compliment: the commentator Olivier Zwartjes has accompanied the difficult situation around the heavy accident well. Then there was again a lack of knowledge of the rules among the commentators Sascha Roos and Ralf Schumacher, so both did not know that you can change tires under a red flag. Although this situation occurred in Imola, Baku, and Silverstone this year, both only came to the conclusion that Verstappen could change tires when there were relevant radio messages about this topic to Hamilton. At Sky UK and RTL, both commentators immediately knew that Verstappen had this option. I am of the opinion that elementary rules should simply be known if you comment on an F1 race for a pay-TV provider. It is also not the first time that something that is now allegedly possible or prescribed according to rules has caused confusion, both have simply had constant uncertainties in the topic of rules. Generally, I don't like the artificial commenting style of Roos, but I have to admit that it is a matter of taste. But what really bothers me is the serious unprofessionalism, such as ordering coffee by the (equally clueless) reporter Peter Hardenacke or "UuuuuHD" by Ralf Schumacher. Especially the latter brings a lot of chaos into the commentary, which he clearly does not take seriously. Not least, advertising takes over completely at Sky, in the final stretch Sky is the only provider that goes into advertising, as you can listen to the German soundtrack without commentary directly after the race on F1TV. Neither ServusTV nor ORF do this. Also, these two providers make less advertising during the training sessions than Sky, and as free-TV providers. Although I have to praise Glock and Baumgartner for their work, this alone does not make up for the disadvantages. The rest of the Sky Sport F1 program is also very sparse and full of repeats. Overall, Sky is really the worst German-speaking provider that broadcasts F1. Ironically, RTL does a better job with the four races they are allowed to broadcast, except for the advertising. So the magnificent F1 season makes significantly less fun than it would be with a reasonable provider. I would be interested in your opinion.
